qas.question: What language has one of the most phonemic orthographies of all European languages?
How many graphemes does Czech have?
What have some of Czech's characters been used for by phonologists to denote?
What character in Czech only exists in loanwords?
In Czech, what type of words do the characters "q", "w" and "x" exclusively appear in?
What character is only used in other European languages?
What do loanwords have more than other European languages?

plausible_answers.text: ň, ě, ř, ť, and ď

qas.question: What letters are common in loanwords?
How many graphemes are there in loanwords?
How many sounds are there in foreign words?

context: <a0_0>Czech<a0_0/> has one of the most <b6_0>phonemic orthographies<b6_0/> of all European languages. Its <a1_0>thirty-one<a1_0/> graphemes represent <b8_0><b9_0>thirty<b9_0/><b8_0/> sounds (in most dialects, i and y have the same sound), and it contains only one digraph: ch, which follows h in the alphabet. As a result, some of its characters have been used by phonologists to denote <a2_0>corresponding sounds in other languages<a2_0/>. The characters q, w and x appear only in <a4_0>foreign<a4_0/> words. The háček (ˇ) is used with certain letters to form new characters: š, ž, and č, as well as <b7_0>ň, ě, ř, ť, and ď<b7_0/> (the latter five uncommon outside Czech). The last two letters are sometimes written with a comma above (ʼ, an abbreviated háček) because of their height. The character <a3_0><b5_0>ó<b5_0/><a3_0/> exists only in loanwords and onomatopoeia.
